body.p: Patricia S. Atkins is a research professor at the George Washington Institute of Public Policy, principally working on research related to state and local tax and fiscal policies. She was previously on the faculty at the University of Baltimore. At the Institute of Public Policy, she also regularly joins research projects focused upon regional economic resilience and interlocal collaboration of governmental services. Her research on urban and regional governance has been published in the Public Manager, Journal of Global Awareness, Public Administration Review, Review of Regional Studies, Journalism Quarterly, and other journals. Her edited book, with David Hamilton, Urban and Regional Policies for Metropolitan Livability was published in 2008. She received her PhD in government and politics from the University of Maryland in 1984.

William R. Barnes has recently retired from the National League of Cities (NLC), where he held various research positions for more than thirty years. While at NLC, he managed projects and authored many professional reports on issues such as public finance, racism and inequity, regional economies, and democratic governance. He wrote regular “Emerging Issues” columns for NLC’s newspaper and for Public Administration Times. He has published articles in scholarly journals, including Urban Affairs Review, Public Administration Review, and Government and Policy. He coauthored The New Regional Economics. He has received numerous awards, including the Donald Store Award in 2010 from the American Society for Public Administration for his contributions to the field of intergovernmental management. He received his PhD in history and metropolitan studies from the Maxwell School at Syracuse University in 1977.

Frank Clifton is the manager of Orange County, NC. He has extensive experience in local government management and has served as a manager of seven other cities or counties in both Florida and Tennessee. He has played a leading role in the establishment of successful community economic development and redevelopment programs and improvement of local government performance in communities suffering from business and industry downturns. He is very active professionally and has served on several International City/County Management Association (ICMA) committees including the ICMA Awards Review Panel. He has also served as the president of the Tennessee City Management Association. He received his masters in city management form East Tennessee State University in 1992.

John Dinan is a professor of politics and international affairs at Wake Forest University. His research on state constitutional processes, state policy, federalism, and health policy has been published in Social Science Journal, Publius, Polity, Journal of Law and Politics, Journal of Regional Analysis and Policy, Southeastern Political Review, and other journals. In addition, he has published numerous law review articles. He has written three books including the Virginia State Constitution that was published in 2011. He received his PhD in politics from the University of Virginia in 1996.

Cheryl A. Hilvert is the director of the Center for Management Studies for the International City/County Management Association. The center provides research, education, and technical assistance regarding best management practices for local governments. Prior to her position with ICMA, she served for more than thirty-one years as a local government administrator, most recently for more than fourteen years as the manager of Montgomery, OH. She has received numerous professional honors including the 2010 Public Administrator of the Year by the Greater Cincinnati Chapter of ASPA and recipient of the 2011 ICMA Program Excellence Award for Strategic Leadership and Governance. She received her master of public administration from Eastern Kentucky University and is also a graduate of the Senior Executive Institute at the University of Virginia and the Economic Development Institute at the University of Oklahoma.

Jennifer M. Jensen is an associate professor of political science and associate dean for academic affairs for Harpur College of Arts and Sciences at the State University of New York at Binghamton. Her research on state politics, intergovernmental relations, interest groups, and political careers has been published in Judicature, Congress and the Presidency, Journal of Policy History, Political Research Quarterly, and State Politics & Policy Quarterly. She is currently completing a book, The Governors’ Lobbyists that is under contract with the University of Michigan Press. She received her PhD in political science from the University of North Carolina in 2000.

Gerald J. Miller is a professor of public affairs at Arizona State University. He was previously on the faculty in the School of Public Affairs and Administration at Rutgers University. His research on public budgeting and finance, personnel management, and other topics has been published in American Review of Public Administration, Journal of Public Budgeting, Accounting and Financial Management, Public Budgeting and Finance, International Journal of Public Administration, Journal of Public Affairs Education, Public Administration Review, Public Administration Quarterly, and many other journals. He has written or edited fifteen books including Government Budgeting and Financial Management in Practice: Logics to Make Sense of Ambiguity that was published in 2011. He received his PhD in political science from the University of Georgia in 1979.

Laura A. Reese is a professor of political science and director of the Global Urban Studies Program at Michigan State University. Her research on economic development, public finance, civic culture, and workplace harassment has been published in Regional Science and Urban Economics, Economic Development Quarterly, Journal of Urban Affairs, American Review of Public Administration, Public Administration Review, Public Personnel Management, Review of Public Personnel Administration, and many other journals. She has written ten books of which three, including Comparative Civic Culture, were published in 2012. She received her PhD in political science from Wayne State University in 1985.

Frank J. Thompson is a professor of public affairs and administration at Rutgers University-Rutgers. He previously served as the dean of the Nelson A. Rockefeller College of Public Affairs and Policy at the State University of New York at Albany. His research on health policy, regulatory federalism, human resource administration, and other topics has been published in Review of Public Personnel Administration, Administration and Society, Journal of Politics, Policy Studies Journal, Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law, Public Administration Review, and many other journals. He has written or edited seven books including Medicaid Politics: Federalism, Policy Durability, and Health Reform that was published in 2012. He received his PhD in political science from the University of California, Berkeley in 1973.

James D. Ward is a professor of political science and coordinator of the public affairs certificate program at Mississippi University for Women. His research on local government management, employment equity, and diversity and public affairs education has been published in the International Journal of Public Administration, Public Administration Review, Journal of Public Affairs Education, Journal of Public Management and Social Policy, Public Productivity and Management, and many other journals. He is very active professionally and has served as a member of the National Council for the American Society for Public Administration and on the board of directors for the Southeastern Conference on Public Administration. He received his PhD in political science from the University of Cincinnati in 1988.
